content: President Obama signed the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2009, providing $106 billion in supplemental FY2009 funds for defense, intelligence activities in Iraq and Afghanistan, international affairs, and domestic purposes. The Department of Health and Human Services received $7.7 billion for pandemic influenza preparedness. On February 23, 2009, an omnibus FY2009 appropriations bill, H.R. 1105, was introduced by the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee. The bill had divisions for nine regular appropriations measures and was passed by the House on February 25 and by the Senate on March 10. It was signed by the President on March 11, 2009, providing $155.0 billion in discretionary funding for the FY2009 L-HHS-ED appropriations. The President signed H.J.Res. 38 into law on March 6, 2009, extending temporary funding for government agencies to March 11, 2009. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 provided emergency supplemental appropriations, including $124.2 billion for discretionary L-HHS-ED programs. It also provided supplemental appropriations for disaster relief and recovery. The bill became P.L. 111-5 on February 17, 2009. For more details, refer to CRS Report RL34711. Interim FY2009 appropriations for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education were provided by Division A of P.L. 110-329, known as the Continuing Appropriations Resolution, 2009. The L-HHS-ED bill is a significant appropriations bill that provides discretionary and mandatory funds to federal departments and agencies, including the Social Security Administration.
